oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Montezuma CME: church
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color photograph of gable-front, concrete-block church. A vestibule with double doors and board siding provides an entrance to the church. Four windows adorn the side of the building. A cemetery sits behind the church and a driveway runs in front of the church.

Montezuma Colored Methodist Episcopal Church is a small church located in Chester County, Tennessee. The church's concrete-block building dates to 1951 and is characteristic of rural, African American churches in the mid-twentieth century South. According to the cornerstone, P.B. Peague Masonic Lodge No. 4 played an active role in the church's early history. A cemetery, located behind the church, serves as the burial area for Montezuma CME. At the time of fieldwork, Reverend Jeremiah Hill was the church's pastor.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African American Churches -- Tennessee
